content: Motorbike taxis in Benin's port of Cotonou. The sector is a major employer and the motorbike taxi unions are influential political actors
- Dahomey becomes an overseas territory of France.
- Dahomey becomes self-governing, within the French Community.
- Dahomey gains independence and is admitted to the UN.
- Elections won by the Parti Dahomeen de L'Unite. Party leader Hubert Maga becomes country's first president.
- President Maga is deposed in a coup led by the army's Chief of Staff, Colonel Christophe Soglo.
Coup leader Colonel Christophe Soglo in 1963. He deposed another leader a few years later
- Sourou-Migan Apithy is elected president.
- General Soglo forces the president to step down and a provisional government is formed. In December he assumes power.
- Major Maurice Kouandete leads a coup. Lt Col Alphonse Alley replaces Gen Soglo as head of state.
- The military regime nominates Dr Emile-Derlin Zinsou as president.
- Lt Col Kouandete deposes President Zinsou.

- Presidential elections are held but abandoned. Power is ceded to a presidential council consisting of Ahomadegbe, Apithy and Maga, who received almost equal support in the abandoned poll. Maga is the first of the three to serve as president with a two-year term.
- Ahomadegbe assumes the presidency from Maga for the next two-year term.
- Socialist Major Mathieu Kerekou seizes power; the presidential council members are detained.
- November - Dahomey is renamed the People's Republic of Benin.
- The Marxist People's Revolutionary Party is made the country's sole political party.
- Parliament unanimously elects sole contender Mr Kerekou as president.
- Members of the former presidential council are released from house arrest.
- Parliament increases the terms of the president and MPs ("people's commissioners") from three to five years. The number of commissioners is reduced from 336 to 196.
- Two unsuccessful coup attempts.
- Benin agrees to IMF and World Bank economic adjustment measures.
- President Kerekou re-elected for a third term, drops Marxism as Benin's official ideology. Anti-government strikes and demonstrations take place.
- Unrest continues. President Kerekou meets dissident leaders. Agreement on constitutional reform and multi-candidate presidential elections is reached.
February - Legislative elections: No party secures an overall majority. The largest grouping is an alliance of pro-Soglo parties.
March - President Kerekou is beaten by Nicephore Soglo in the first multi-candidate presidential elections. Kerekou is granted immunity from prosecution over actions taken since October 1972.
- Legislative elections sees pro-Soglo liberal Renaissance Party form the new government.
- Following accusations of irregularities in presidential elections, the constitutional court returns Mr Kerekou to office.
- Legislative elections sees coalition government formed by 10 parties.
March - Mr Kerekou re-elected president.
December - First local elections since the end of the single-party regime more than 10 years earlier.
March - Legislative elections: Parties supporting President Kerekou win 52 of the 83 elective seats.
July - International Court of Justice awards most of the river islands along the disputed Benin-Niger border to Niger.
March - Political newcomer Yayi Boni, running as an independent, wins the run-off vote in presidential elections. President Kerekou is barred from the poll under a constitutional age limit.
April - World Bank and the African Development Bank approve debt relief for several countries including Benin
April - President Yayi's coalition wins control of parliament in elections.
April - Parties allied with President Yayi win a majority of local council seats nationwide, but the major cities in the south are all won by opposition parties.
February - Benin announces discovery of "significant quantities" of oil offshore near Seme, a town on the Nigeria-Benin border.
March - President Yayi is re-elected. His main challenger, Adrien Houngbedji, alleges widespread fraud
May - President Yayi's party and its allies regain control of parliament in elections.
May - President Yayi's party loses parliamentary majority in elections.
President Patrice Talon
March - Businessman Patrice Talon is elected president, defeating outgoing President Boni Yayi's candidate, Prime Minister Lionel Zinsou.
April - Parliament narrowly rejects President Talon's proposal to to restrict his successors to a single six-year term, which he said would reduce "presidential complacency".

April - Parliamentary elections marked by low turnout. The electoral commission, dominated by allies of President Talon, bans all opposition parties from standing. Several people are killed and scores injured in pre-poll violence in opposition strongholds in northern and eastern parts of the country.
